div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 954px; height: 1px; padding-top: 7px; margin-left: 281px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Verdana; color: rgb(77, 77, 77); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: Containers have rapidly become the standard for packaging and running distributed applications, including microservices and functions. The creation of modular, reusable containers is a key prerequisite for cloud-native applications. The term "cloud-native" refers to principles, patterns, and tools for automating containerized applications at scale. It's often used interchangeably with k8s, the leading open-source platform for cloud-native applications today

switch.text: Containers have rapidly become the standard for packaging and running distributed applications, including microservices and functions. The creation of modular,...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 954px; height: 1px; padding-top: 97px; margin-left: 281px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Verdana; color: rgb(77, 77, 77); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: The microservices architecture and 12-factor app methodology have become standard for designing distributed applications. These principles enable the development of implementations that are scalable, resilient, and adaptable to change - key requirements for modern software

switch.text: The microservices architecture and 12-factor app methodology have become standard for designing distributed applications. These principles enable the developme...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 954px; height: 1px; padding-top: 157px; margin-left: 281px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Verdana; color: rgb(77, 77, 77); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: Hexagonal, Onion, and Clean architectures enhance application flexibility and maintainability by separating components and establishing standard interaction interfaces. They isolate core business logic from infrastructure, facilitating system portability across environments or platforms. These architectures, which align well with domain-driven design, organize application code with clear boundaries and externalized infrastructure dependencies

switch.text: Hexagonal, Onion, and Clean architectures enhance application flexibility and maintainability by separating components and establishing standard interaction in...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 954px; height: 1px; padding-top: 237px; margin-left: 281px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Verdana; color: rgb(77, 77, 77); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: Domain-driven design (DDD) is a software design approach that emphasizes business perspective and real-world modelling. It's particularly effective with object-oriented programming, but can be applied elsewhere. A well-defined model with appropriate business and transaction boundaries, user-friendly interfaces, and robust APls forms the basis for successful containerization and automation

switch.text: Domain-driven design (DDD) is a software design approach that emphasizes business perspective and real-world modelling. It's particularly effective with object...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 954px; height: 1px; padding-top: 317px; margin-left: 281px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Verdana; color: rgb(77, 77, 77); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: Every piece of code, from variables to methods and classes, significantly influences the long-term maintenance of an application. Regardless of the container technology or orchestration platform used, the development team and their artifacts are crucial. It's vital to foster developers who aim for clean code, appropriate automated testing, continuous refactoring for code quality improvement, and adhere to Software Craftsmanship principles
